summary: This narrative review synthesizes literature on onboarding anesthesia professionals, outlining structured orientation, simulation-based training, mentorship, feedback, and socialization. It highlights patient safety, clinician well-being, team performance, and retention benefits, describes implementation strategies, and presents a case study from a large academic center.
strengths: Comprehensive overview of core onboarding components across multiple roles
Practical, actionable recommendations with a real-world case example
weaknesses: Narrative review design lacks systematic rigour and bias assessment
Limited use of validated evaluation instruments and theoretical models

summary: This article reports the Co-Pilot Project, an ongoing collaborative initiative between U.S. and Ukrainian physicians delivering neurosurgical capacity building in wartime Ukraine. It details a mission trip to Lviv in April–May 2023, describing team composition (neurosurgeons, anesthesiologists, interventional radiologist, technical support, trainees), logistics (equipment donation, travel safety, lodging, evacuation planning), clinical activities (complex tumor, spine, endovascular cases), an illustrative far-lateral craniotomy case, and recommendations for sustaining long-term partnerships and education via in-person and virtual follow-up.
strengths: Comprehensive description of logistics and safety planning in a conflict zone
Detailed illustrative surgical case with intraoperative technique
Long-term partnership model with virtual follow-up and education
Practical recommendations for global surgical missions
weaknesses: No discussion of onboarding concepts or processes for new physicians
Lacks formal methodology, data collection, and evaluation metrics
Does not reference digital tools or IT platforms for training or coordination
No theoretical frameworks to guide educational or organizational aspects

summary: The article describes the North American Neuromodulation Society’s development of a standardized educational curriculum for implanting and managing vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) devices in epilepsy care. A multidisciplinary subcommittee used an iterative, consensus-based process mapped to the ACGME six core competencies to define role- and level-specific attributes for early learners, advanced learners, and independent practitioners. The result is a cross-discipline framework distinguishing proceduralist and managing-clinician competencies to guide training, evaluation, and credentialing.

Structured use of ACGME core competencies and milestones framework
Clear role differentiation between implanting and managing providers
weaknesses: No empirical validation or pilot testing of the curriculum
Lacks defined evaluation metrics and safety analysis
Does not provide case studies or detailed implementation guidance

summary: This qualitative study explores how second-year residents in two Dutch hospitals adapt to residency (TTR) through their own strategies and organizational strategies encountered, using Organizational Socialization theory. Interviews with 16 residents revealed five individual strategies (observing, asking questions, experimenting, establishing social relationships, seeking information) and six organizational tactics (collective–individual, formal–informal, sequential–random, fixed–variable, serial–disjunctive, investiture–divestiture). The study shows that these strategies interact, impacting adaptation positively or negatively, and that residents vary in preferring autonomy versus structured guidance, suggesting customized onboarding support.

Diverse sample across multiple specialties and two hospital settings enhances contextual richness.
Rigorous qualitative methodology with reflexivity and audit trail supports credibility of findings.
weaknesses: No formal evaluation metrics or outcome measures to gauge onboarding effectiveness.
Lack of technological integration or discussion of digital onboarding tools.
Small convenience sample limits generalizability; retrospective recall may bias responses.

summary: This commentary outlines the role of structured mentorship in pain medicine across career stages. It reviews literature on mentorship benefits for research skills, clinical competence, multidisciplinary collaboration, and diversity, equity, and inclusion. summary: This article documents a decade‐long plateau and relative decline in pediatric anesthesiology fellowship enrollment despite growth in residency positions. It reviews national ACGME data, surveys, and literature to describe the workforce shortage, its effects on hospitals, practices, and patients, and proposes a multifaceted response: leadership initiatives, outreach to students and residents, financial incentives, policy changes, international pathways, wellness programs, and continuous workforce monitoring.

summary: This cross-sectional web-based survey of 406 European anesthesiologists explored mentor-mentee relationship dynamics, preferences, facilitators, and barriers, with a focus on gender and ethnicity influences. Key findings: personal compatibility and mentor experience drive successful pairings; time constraints and perceived lack of interest hinder relationships; mentorship benefits mentees’ clinical skills and support, and mentors’ sense of helpfulness and resilience against burnout/impostor syndrome; women and non-white participants report distinct barriers and needs.

Detailed analysis of gender and ethnicity influences using logistic regression.
Clear identification of key facilitators and barriers for mentors and mentees.

summary: This cross-sectional survey studied 235 anesthesiology & intensive care (AIC) and emergency medicine (EM) residents across 11 Romanian centers. Using a 42-item Likert questionnaire and open-ended questions, it evaluated perceptions of curriculum structure, training environment, mentorship, teaching methods, and assessment. Data analysis included Cronbach’s alpha, ICC, nonparametric tests, and thematic coding. Results show comparable overall satisfaction but identify gaps in mentor availability, interactive teaching, and feedback. Authors recommend enhanced mentorship, simulation, AR/VR training, and longitudinal/multicenter studies.

Comprehensive statistical analysis with reliability measures
Balanced comparison of two critical care specialties

summary: This single-center, prospective, randomized controlled trial compared human cadaver versus blue phantom models for teaching ultrasound-guided supraclavicular brachial plexus block to 50 novice anesthesiology trainees. Participants were randomized to 30 practice attempts on either model, followed by assessment of block performance time, image quality, transducer orientation, artifact identification, procedural errors, complications, and success rate on patients. Cadaver-trained novices achieved significantly faster block times, better image quality and transducer stability, and fewer needle passes. Complications and success rates were comparable between groups.
strengths: Rigorous randomized controlled design with adequate sample size and power calculation.
Objective, quantifiable performance measures and blinded outcome assessment.
weaknesses: Single-center setting limits external validity and scalability assessment.
No integration of nontechnical skill evaluation or long-term retention outcomes.

criteria_scores.justification: The article focuses solely on clinical education and simulation without administrative, technological integration beyond ultrasound hardware, or educational theory.

summary: This Q-methodology study explores preferences of 51 early-career medical residents across eight Dutch hospitals for organizational socialization strategies during transitions. Four distinct resident viewpoints emerged—Dependent, Social Capitalizing, Autonomous, and Development-oriented—each differing in desired levels of structure, guidance, and social interaction. The findings underscore the inadequacy of one-size-fits-all onboarding and recommend tailoring strategies to individual needs to enhance autonomy, competence, and relatedness.

Strong linkage between theory and practice with clear recommendations for tailored onboarding.
weaknesses: Lack of objective evaluation metrics and safety considerations.

Fifteen participants showed significant improvements in intubation and echocardiography skills (P < 0.05), increased interest in anesthesia, and greater preparedness for future rotations.

summary: The article reviews systemic barriers faced by mid-career women anesthesiologists—insufficient actionable feedback, lack of mentorship and sponsorship, bias in leadership metrics, overload of nonpromotable work, workplace mistreatment, burnout, and personal demands of parenthood. It concludes with recommendations for structured mentorship, targeted leadership training, strategic project selection, and inclusive promotion criteria.

Actionable recommendations for mentorship, leadership development, and promotion criteria reform.

summary: This retrospective single-center study compares outcomes of thoracoscopic versus open thoracotomy resections for congenital pulmonary airway malformations in children from 2013 to 2020. Through a structured mentorship by an expert surgeon, the local team performed 50 thoracoscopic resections with zero conversions, shorter length of stay, and fewer complications compared to 30 open cases. The authors conclude that a mentorship program enables safe adoption of technically demanding pediatric thoracoscopic lobectomy, shifts practice paradigms, and yields clinical benefits such as reduced morbidity and faster recovery.

Structured mentorship enabled local surgeons to safely adopt a complex procedure

weaknesses: Retrospective single-center design limits generalizability

summary: This study surveyed 235 anesthesiology, intensive care, and emergency medicine residents across 11 Romanian centers to assess four domains of their training: curriculum structure, learning environment, mentorship, and teaching methods. Using an anonymous online questionnaire with 42 Likert-scale items, supplemented by qualitative questions, the authors calculated scale reliability (Cronbach's alpha, ICC) and performed nonparametric statistical analyses. Key findings show similar overall feedback for both specialties but highlight gaps in mentor availability, structured feedback, and interactive educational experiences. The authors recommend enhancing mentorship, adopting simulation/AR/VR technologies, and planning multicenter longitudinal studies.

summary: This longitudinal cohort study examined the long-term impact of a two-year faculty development program for junior anesthesia faculty at the University of Iowa (2009–2019) on scholarly output from 2006 to 2022. Among 128 faculty, 41% completed the program. Those who completed had a 17% absolute increase in the probability of ≥1 publication per year and produced on average 1.7 more publications annually (95% CI 1.1–2.4, P<.0001). Publications were heavily skewed, with the top 10% of faculty accounting for over half of annual outputs. Leaving the institution modestly reduced output. The program included nonclinical time, dual mentorship, individualized goals, seminars, and financial support.

summary: This report describes the development and implementation of a nine-month, guideline-aligned POCUS certification program for critical care nurse practitioners and physician assistants at a tertiary cancer center. summary: This quasi-experimental study describes a low-cost, pork-based ultrasound-guided central venous catheterization (CVC) simulator used to train 33 anesthesiology residents. The workshop included a short lecture, orientation, and hands-on practice. Pre- and post-training questionnaires and objective skills evaluations demonstrated significant improvements in residents’ confidence and procedural competency. The model cost $6.68 and took 7.3 minutes to assemble.

summary: This study describes the development, implementation, and mixed‐methods evaluation of Pediatric Project ECHO® for Pain, a virtual, interprofessional education program for health care providers (HCPs) managing acute and chronic pediatric pain. A needs assessment informed a curriculum spanning pharmacological, physical, and psychological approaches. The program delivered 85 TeleECHO sessions and two core curricula via Zoom from 2017–2022, with a mean attendance of 34 HCPs per session. Surveys at baseline and six months showed significant improvements in self‐reported knowledge and self‐efficacy across most topics and skills. Participants rated the program as acceptable and reported positive impacts on clinical practice. Exploratory analysis suggested greater community‐driven engagement during the COVID‐19 pandemic.

weaknesses: No control group or randomized comparison, reliance on unvalidated self‐report measures.

summary: This article reports a formative evaluation of a 90-minute orientation session for new chronic pain patients at The Ottawa Hospital Pain Clinic. Through semistructured telephone interviews with 12 of 18 attendees, thematic analysis identified strengths—sense of community, feeling heard, holistic approach, awareness of community resources—and weaknesses—geographic and scheduling barriers and mixed feelings of preparedness for physician appointments. The paper concludes that the orientation improves pain literacy, reduces isolation, and instills hope, and suggests virtual delivery and further comparisons of delivery methods.

summary: This article reviews the persistent challenges in anesthesiology research—low NIH funding, limited protected time, and scarce mentorship—and proposes the Introduction to Clinical Research for Academic Anesthesiologists (ICRAA) year-long course. The course aims to equip early career anesthesiologists with skills in study design, data analysis collaboration, manuscript writing, and critical appraisal through interactive lectures, workshops, and mentored activities.

summary: This retrospective study describes a 9–10-week competence-based simulation orientation program for new and experienced respiratory therapists in a pediatric hospital. Participants completed pre- and post-orientation simulation scenarios and competency validations. Over four iterative time periods, the curriculum was refined with weighted checklists, introductory videos, expanded didactics, workshops, and clinical proficiency observations. Statistical comparison of pre- versus post-simulation scores showed significant improvements, and 71% of orientees advanced to intensive care orientation.

summary: This prospective, observational pilot study at a single ACGME-accredited RAAPM fellowship evaluated fellows’ knowledge acquisition over an academic year using a standardized 89-question exam administered at orientation, 4 months, and 8 months. Scores improved from 64% to 74% to 79%, with most learning occurring in the first half of the year. Topic-level analysis identified initial gaps in lower extremity blocks, truncal blocks, and neuraxial anesthesia, guiding future curriculum adjustments.

summary: This narrative review outlines the importance of structured, stage-specific mentorship in anesthesiology training—from medical student through early faculty. It defines mentorship domains (career enhancement and psychosocial support), describes models (near-peer, faculty networks, academic village), and proposes a 5-step implementation framework (rationale, mentee education, tailored programs, mentor profiles, relationship facilitation).

summary: This qualitative study uses constructivist grounded theory to explore how 26 female anesthesiology leaders in North America acquire leadership positions. Four themes emerged: key personality traits (perseverance, adaptability), leadership preparation (mentorship, networking, formal training), gender-related considerations (bias, work–family conflict), and leadership acquisition strategies (self-promotion, sponsorship). The authors recommend formal sponsorship programs to reduce the gender leadership gap.

High-value sample of experienced leaders across academia and professional societies.
weaknesses: Does not address onboarding processes or frameworks.

summary: This multi-institutional study describes a one-day simulation and procedural bootcamp for first-year clinical anesthesia (CA-1) residents at two academic centers. The bootcamp combined high-fidelity simulation scenarios and partial task trainers to teach airway management, neuraxial and vascular access procedures, and management of intraoperative complications. Pre- and post-bootcamp surveys (Likert comfort ratings) showed significant improvement in self-perceived procedural comfort across all domains. Analysis of Anesthesia Knowledge Test (AKT) scores before and one month after training revealed no significant knowledge gain. The curriculum proved reproducible across institutions.

Combination of high-fidelity simulation and task trainers addresses core anesthesiology skills.

summary: This interrupted time series study evaluated a bundled quality improvement (QI) intervention at Mount Sinai Hospital to reduce opioid prescriptions at discharge after Cesarean delivery. Interventions included resident orientation instructions, nursing and patient education, posters, and electronic discharge prescriptions. Among 2,578 women (six months pre- and six months post-intervention), mean discharge opioids decreased from 97.6 MME to 35.8 MME (–61.7 MME, P<0.001), with no increase in postnatal pain clinic visits.

High-fidelity implementation across clinical, nursing, patient, and IT domains.
weaknesses: Bundled intervention prevents determination of each component’s individual impact.
Single-center study with no patient-reported outcomes or formal safety metrics.

summary: The study qualitatively evaluated the first iteration of the Acute Care Operational Research (ACOR) course, a blended SORT-IT model, delivered to anesthesiology residents in Kigali. Using semi-structured interviews with 12 participants (6 students, 4 primary mentors, 2 secondary mentors), two independent coders identified facilitators and barriers. Key facilitators included structured milestones and mentorship, while barriers were limited time, mentor availability, background knowledge gaps, and infrastructure challenges. Cultural hierarchy played a minor role. The authors propose enhancing mentor training, adjusting timelines, and improving support for future iterations and similar programs.

summary: This study describes a four-year Medical Education Reform Program (MERP) in the Department of Anesthesiology and Critical Care at Shahid Beheshti University. The reform targeted education and research indices through structured steps: SWOT analysis, stakeholder engagement, committee planning, implementation, monitoring, and documentation. Nine education and three research indices were defined and measured, demonstrating significant improvements in teaching methods, assessments, mentorship, faculty development, professionalism, integration, crisis management, targeted research activities, innovative research approaches, and research impact.

summary: The article describes the development, implementation, and early evaluation of the Women’s Empowerment and Leadership Initiative (WELI) by the Society for Pediatric Anesthesia. WELI pairs women pediatric anesthesiologists (protégés) with experienced advisors, provides workshops, virtual networking (GAIN), and online resources to foster career development, leadership skills, mentorship, networking, goal setting, and well-being. After two years, a 60.5% survey response showed high perceived value in selection, dyads, workshops, and networking. Qualitative themes included empowerment, skills acquisition, goal clarity, networking benefits, and COVID-19–related challenges. Early outcomes suggest WELI supports career progress, with longer-term effects on promotion and leadership positions pending further study.

summary: This single‐institution survey of 103 academic anesthesiologists examined the presence of mentorship, gender differences in mentor selection, and associations with age, career stage, and work status. Thirty percent reported having a mentor (84% of mentors were men), with younger, early‐career, full‐time physicians more likely to have mentors. Women beyond assistant professor rank reported fewer mentors. Respondents overwhelmingly agreed mentorship was important for academic success, yet formal programs were lacking. Logistic regression and exact tests identified significant associations and interactions by gender.

summary: This cross-sectional survey of 50 anesthesiology residents and 3 program directors in Riyadh assessed the prevalence, perceived benefits, and barriers of mentorship in anesthesia training. Half of residents reported having a mentor, primarily formal and anesthesiologist mentors. Residents viewed mentorship as beneficial for career advancement, clinical skill development, and confidence building. Reported barriers included lack of skilled mentors, insufficient time, lack of formalized objectives and meeting times, and poor mentor–mentee compatibility.

summary: This article details the design, implementation, and early observations of MentorME, a mentee-driven mentorship program for anesthesiology residents at Emory University. Components include self-nominated faculty mentors, online mentor competency training, mentee-driven mentor selection, mentoring contracts, and action plan templates. Early outcomes show high mentee engagement, improved self-assessed mentor competencies via the Mentor Competency Assessment tool, and robust meeting compliance.

summary: The article reports implementation of two speed mentoring events for women faculty and trainees in an academic anesthesiology department. Baseline and follow-up surveys measured satisfaction with mentorship and number of mentors identified. Results showed increased satisfaction and stable growth in mentor relationships at 6–12 months. The intervention is low-cost, requires minimal time, and may help address mentorship gaps for women in academic medicine.

Simple, low-cost approach with high participant satisfaction
weaknesses: Small, uncontrolled sample with survey attrition over time
Lack of validated measures and theoretical grounding

summary: This article describes the design, implementation, and evaluation of a two-hour workshop to prepare senior anesthesiology residents to train junior residents in the operating room. Grounded in cognitive load theory, Bloom’s taxonomy, self-determination theory, and the one-minute preceptor microskills model, the workshop combined didactic slides with small-group practice. Pre-, post-, one-week, and one-month surveys measured resident confidence, knowledge of teaching principles, and CA1 perceptions of trainers. Results showed immediate gains in trainers’ confidence (75% to 100%) and knowledge (0% to 83%), but knowledge retention dropped at one month. The authors discuss digital distribution, virtual adaptations, reinforcement strategies, and future directions.
strengths: Well-structured workshop grounded in multiple educational theories
Clear measurement of immediate gains in teaching confidence and knowledge
Adaptable digital and virtual delivery suggestions
weaknesses: Small sample size with low long-term follow-up response rates
No control group or objective performance measures
Rapid decay of knowledge without reinforcement
Lacks formal change management and safety analysis

summary: The article describes a 5-day, high-fidelity Simulation Boot Camp (SBC) for first-year anesthesiology residents over 2006–2016. Participants completed two individualized intraoperative simulations daily with debriefing, and self-efficacy for 25 anesthesia skills was measured before and after each course. Analysis of 267 participants showed significant improvements in summed self-efficacy (mean increase 38 points/250) across all skill domains. Secondary analyses found baseline differences in self-efficacy by sex, video-gaming experience, and prior residency, with women showing greater gains. Postcourse evaluations and thematic analysis of free-text comments indicated high satisfaction. The program was sustained over a decade with consistent results.
strengths: Large, decade-long cohort with consistent program delivery
Mixed-methods evaluation combining quantitative self-efficacy and qualitative feedback
High fidelity simulation closely replicating real OR scenarios
weaknesses: No control or comparison group to isolate simulation effect
Reliance on self-reported confidence without objective performance measures
Limited discussion of administrative, IT, and change-management frameworks

summary: This study surveys 56 of 156 U.S. anesthesiology residency programs (36% response rate) to describe current orientation practices for first-year clinical anesthesiology residents. Key findings include common 1:1 pairing with faculty or senior residents for an average of 4–6 weeks, a median of 30 hours of dedicated introductory didactics (lectures, simulations, online content, and case-based learning), and varied timing and assessment methods for initiating call duties. Formal 'train-the-trainer' education is provided by 44% of programs. The authors outline program heterogeneity and suggest future research linking orientation methods to objective performance metrics.

summary: The article describes the development and evaluation of a 1-day advanced simulation-based boot camp for graduating pediatric anesthesiology fellows from nine academic centers. It uses high-fidelity scenarios, skill stations, standardized patients, and reflective modules to enhance knowledge, confidence, and transition readiness. Participants rated the curriculum positively on knowledge gain, self-confidence, case complexity, and transition tools over two consecutive years, and iterative feedback refined the program.

summary: This retrospective descriptive study evaluated the impact of an Integrative Educational Intervention (IEI) package—comprising individualized mentorship, monthly in-training written exams, and periodic mock OSCEs—on the relative annual pass rate (RAPR) of anesthesiology residents at Shahid Beheshti University of Medical Sciences (SBMU) from 2012 to 2019. After implementation, RAPR improved significantly (Spearman’s rho=0.655, P=0.039), indicating a positive correlation between the IEI and board exam success.

Longitudinal data over eight years with quantitative outcomes
weaknesses: Retrospective design with no control group or confounder adjustment

summary: This observational case-control study evaluated whether adding part-task simulation training to Pecha Kucha–based instruction improves anesthesiology residents’ fiberoptic tracheal intubation skills on fresh frozen cadavers. Eighteen junior residents were randomized to part-task or whole-task training following a standardized 6m40s Pecha Kucha presentation. The part-task group showed higher success rates in Aintree catheter insertion and tube placement. No significant differences in complication rates or intubation times were found. The authors conclude that combining Pecha Kucha with part-task training may enhance airway management education.

Randomized group assignment and clear stepwise training protocol
weaknesses: Small sample size and single-center design limit generalizability

summary: This single‐institution, prospective cohort study evaluated an eight-module online, asynchronous perioperative evaluation course for PGY-1 anesthesiology residents. Control residents (n=20) received no intervention, whereas intervention residents (n=25) completed voluntary pretests, readings, lecture videos, case discussions, and posttests over eight months. Outcomes included module test score gains, first-day Anesthesia Knowledge Test (AKT-0) percentiles, and pre-vs-post surveys on comfort, knowledge, and anxiety. Intervention residents improved 16–40 percentage points per module (P<.0001), scored 24 percentile points higher on AKT-0 (P=.0488), and reported reduced anxiety and increased comfort on most measures. The course used Blackboard, Vcasmo, and Vimeo for delivery.

High resident engagement despite voluntary participation.
Integration of multimodal digital delivery (readings, videos, forums).
weaknesses: Lack of randomized control limits causal inference.
Survey instrument was not validated.
No formal definition of onboarding or theoretical framework applied.

summary: This survey study of 1,199 U.S. anesthesiologists assessed practice management and transition-to-practice (TTP) training during residency. Results showed low exposure to formal TTP curricula and mentorship, unfamiliarity with resources, and desire for enhanced business education. Respondents in practice ≤10 years reported slightly better curricular exposure but still significant gaps. The authors recommend establishing structured TTP curricula, formal mentorship, and promotion of external resources.

summary: This narrative review outlines foundational guidance for junior clinician-investigators in pain research, covering motivation, mentorship, concept development, study design (with emphasis on RCTs), IRB/regulatory processes, outcome selection, sample size calculation, protocol preparation, trial registration, and funding pathways. summary: This retrospective cohort study describes a structured mentorship program for anesthesiology residents at Shahid Beheshti University. Twelve faculty mentors and all nine educational wards participated in online group discussions, scheduled textbook chapters, monthly formative and summative exams (PMP, OSCE, MCQs), and role-playing for stress management. Outcomes compared pre-intervention (2014–2015) vs post-intervention (2016–2017, 2018–2019) showed significant improvements in IBAITE scores and first-time board exam pass rates, demonstrating the program’s positive impact on theoretical knowledge, clinical skills, and professional development.

Comprehensive monthly assessment and feedback loop involving both learners and faculty.
weaknesses: Lacks formal definition of onboarding and theoretical frameworks to guide design.

summary: This single-center study describes a two-phase perioperative ultrasound training program for anesthesia faculty. Phase one consisted of six didactic and hands-on sessions with quizzes and an OSCE; phase two provided individualized proctored training and supervised clinical practice. Outcomes included significant improvement in quiz and OSCE scores, positive session feedback, and demonstration of procedural proficiency in regional anesthesia and transthoracic echocardiography.

weaknesses: Single-center descriptive design without control or multi-site validation

summary: This single-institution study assessed VARK learning preferences of 18 CA-1 anesthesiology residents during their July orientation. Residents were randomized to know or not know their VARK results, and resource use was tracked via survey cards. Results showed no difference in resource utilization between groups, a predominance of aural and read/write resources, and that 72% of residents’ preferences shifted over the month.

Pre- and post-intervention measurement captures shifts in learning preferences over time.
weaknesses: Small sample size from a single institution limits generalizability.
Lacks statistical analysis details, formal onboarding definition, and implementation framework.

It highlights heterogeneity in CBY designs, common rotations (emergency medicine, ICUs, anesthesia month), novel curriculum additions (simulation, perioperative surgical home, practice management), and existing strategies for intern support.

summary: This narrative review describes four short subspecialty anesthesia courses (PTC, EPM, SAFE-OB, SAFE-Paeds) designed for low- and middle-income countries. It covers rationale, content, structure, costs, global uptake, and preliminary evaluations. The courses use interactive teaching and a train-the-teacher model to promote local ownership, sustainability, and scalability. Although short‐term knowledge and skill gains are documented, the article highlights limited published data on patient outcomes and calls for more rigorous evaluation.

summary: This article describes the design, implementation, and iterative evaluation of a week-long Junior Faculty Academic Core Curriculum at the University of Rochester. Developed through focus groups, collaboration between CTSI and Faculty Development, and ongoing feedback, the program targets clinical and research faculty, covering research methods, grant writing, teaching, career planning, and networking. Daily and 6-month evaluations informed annual modifications, including expanding to PhD faculty and parallel sessions for researchers vs. educators. summary: This cross-sectional survey of 189 Canadian anesthesia residents and 16 program directors examined perceptions, prevalence, and barriers to formal mentorship in anesthesia residency. While 79% of residents valued mentorship for career and skills development, only 69% of programs had formal mentorship and 63% of residents had a mentor. Barriers included insufficient time, lack of formal objectives, poor mentor–mentee matching, and limited resident choice. Most programs assign mentors top-down. Authors recommend clearer objectives, scheduled meetings, and resident-driven mentor selection.

summary: This qualitative study explores anesthesia trainees’ experiences transitioning to a pediatric hospital. In-depth interviews with 31 trainees revealed two main challenges: feeling ineffective (cognitive disorientation and emotional perceptions of uselessness) and heightened anxiety or fear. The authors discuss how these factors impair learning and suggest strategies—such as structured orientation, peer support, graduated responsibility, and supervisor-led debriefs—to mitigate negative impacts during transition.

summary: This article reports a national needs assessment, development, implementation, and preliminary evaluation of an Anesthesiology Resident Wellness Program (ARWP) at the University of Saskatchewan. Using a mixed-methods approach (survey and focus group of program directors), the authors identified gaps in formal wellness curricula across Canadian anesthesiology programs. They then built a four-component ARWP (modular curriculum, peer support, self-directed activities, department wellness initiatives), piloted it over two years, and surveyed 28 residents, finding high satisfaction and perceived applicability to work and life.

summary: This article provides a concise practical guide for medical students during anesthesia rotations in adults. It covers professionalism, preoperative assessment, monitoring, airway management, induction and maintenance of general anesthesia, choice of anesthetic agents, regional techniques (spinal, epidural, peripheral blocks), fluid management, and postoperative analgesia. Hands-on skills like IV cannulation, mask ventilation, and intubation are illustrated via QR-code–linked web videos to enhance learning and engagement.
strengths: Comprehensive, step-by-step clinical coverage of anesthesia basics for students.
Integration of QR-code–linked videos enhances visual learning and skill acquisition.
Clear practice-oriented summary section ('Fazit') concisely highlights take-home messages.
weaknesses: Lacks empirical validation or assessment of learning outcomes.
No formal educational framework or theoretical underpinning.
Absence of implementation strategy or stakeholder engagement guidance.

criteria_scores.justification: The guide is primarily clinical and educational with a brief mention of web-based video technology but lacks administrative or IT system integration.

summary: This study surveyed 131 ACGME-accredited anesthesiology residency program directors in the US (34% response) to assess the prevalence and characteristics of formal mentorship programs. Of respondents, 88% reported a formal mentorship program, with variability in mentor-mentee pairing methods and meeting frequency. Few programs provided faculty mentor training (37%) or evaluated program effectiveness (16–21%). Program directors highly value mentorship for career planning, professionalism, and work–life balance but note gaps in structure, training, and evaluation. The authors call for resident-centered research and systematic program assessments to optimize mentorship models.
strengths: First national survey characterizing mentorship structures in anesthesiology residencies
Detailed breakdown of program characteristics and director attitudes
Identifies clear gaps in training and evaluation practices
weaknesses: Low response rate (34%) introduces potential response bias
Lack of resident or mentor perspectives limits understanding of program efficacy
No outcome or effectiveness measures to assess real-world impact

summary: This randomized, double-blinded educational trial compared two transducer orientations (perpendicular vs parallel to the trainee’s shoulders) for ultrasound-guided regional anesthesia in true novices using a gelatin phantom. Participants watched standardized instructional videos, then performed three simulated nerve block tasks. The perpendicular orientation group completed the tasks faster and maintained needle visualization more consistently than the parallel group.
strengths: Randomized, double-blinded design with concealed allocation minimizes bias.
Objective quantitative metrics and blinded assessment strengthen internal validity.
Clear reporting of methods and statistical analysis enhances reproducibility.
weaknesses: Use of low-fidelity gelatin phantom limits generalizability to clinical practice.
True novices only; findings may not apply to learners with prior ultrasound or medical experience.
No long-term retention or transfer to patient care outcomes assessed.

criteria_scores.justification: The study focuses solely on clinical education of ultrasound skills and does not incorporate administrative, technological, or broader organizational domains.
Well-designed randomized, double-blinded trial with power estimation and statistical analysis; limitations (phantom model, sample size) are clearly acknowledged.

summary: This study describes the design and implementation of a 1-week preclinical elective in anesthesiology, critical care, and perioperative medicine for first- and second-year medical students at Mayo Medical School. The curriculum combined didactic sessions, hands-on workshops in airway management and vascular access, operating room shadowing, and mentorship events. Pre- and post-selective surveys (n=8) showed significant self-reported gains in knowledge, procedural comfort, and interest in the specialty.
strengths: Well-structured curriculum combining didactic, skills workshops, and mentorship
Complete pre/post survey response rate with basic statistical analysis
weaknesses: Very small, self-selected sample limits generalizability
Reliance on subjective self-assessment without objective outcome measures

summary: This qualitative study explored mentorship in anesthesiology at the University of Ottawa by interviewing 11 residents and 12 faculty. Three key factors influencing success emerged: defined goals of the relationship, characteristics of mentors and mentees, and program structure. Junior residents valued psychosocial support; senior residents prioritized career guidance. The authors propose mentorship networks, clear guidelines, transparent matching, and faculty development to improve residency mentorship.
strengths: Rigorous qualitative methodology with thematic analysis and triangulation
Inclusion of both mentor and mentee perspectives across training levels
Practical, actionable recommendations for program structure
weaknesses: Single‐center study limits generalizability
No structured evaluation metrics or long‐term outcomes
Lacks integration of theoretical frameworks

criteria_scores.justification: Focuses on educational/mentorship domain with minimal reference to other areas; lacks clinical–administrative–IT integration.

summary: This article presents a cross-sectional survey of 132 ACGME-accredited U.S. anesthesiology residency programs, with a 66% response rate (87 programs). It characterizes simulation-based education and assessment practices: course structure, frequency, content areas, assessment/remediation uses, faculty involvement, obstacles, and interest in standardization. Findings reveal wide variation in simulation curricula, common barriers of time, funding, and staffing, and broad support (89%) for standardizing key components (e.g., clinical scenarios, crisis resource management, debriefing).
strengths: High survey response rate (66%) across a national cohort.
Detailed characterization of simulation practices, barriers, and faculty involvement.
weaknesses: Descriptive design lacks outcome measures or validated evaluation.
No coherent change management strategy or case studies to guide implementation.

criteria_scores.justification: The survey offers an item on interdisciplinary simulation but provides no integrated model across clinical, administrative, and IT domains.

summary: This cross-sectional web-based survey assessed the prevalence and characteristics of formal and informal mentorship among Canadian anesthesiology residents and training programs. Thirteen program directors (76% response) and 203 residents (39% response) reported that 54% of programs had formal mentorship, 74% of residents identified a mentor, and 42% did not meet regularly. Formal programs were associated with higher rates of mentorship and regular interaction.
strengths: High response rate from program directors (76%) with clear program-level data.
Detailed survey instrument with pilot testing and defined mentorship terms.
weaknesses: Low resident response rate (39%) introduces potential selection bias.
No inferential statistics or longitudinal outcome measures to assess impact.
